skill.name: extract
skill.description: Extract content from specific URLs using Tavily's extraction API. Returns clean markdown/text from web pages. Use when you have specific URLs and need their content without writing code.
skill.summary: Extract clean content from specific URLs using Tavily's API. Returns markdown or text from web pages.
skill.author: tavily-ai

security_audit.summary: All 137 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is a legitimate web content extraction tool that uses shell commands (jq, curl) to make authenticated API calls to Tavily's service. Network calls go to official Tavily API endpoints. Filesystem access is for reading OAuth tokens from standard locations. Environment access is for reading the user-provided API key.

high_findings.title: Shell Command Execution
high_findings.description: Shell commands (jq, curl, base64) used for API operations. These are standard tools for JSON parsing and HTTP requests. No user input injection risk.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Pattern matches shell commands but these are legitimate API client operations - no user-controlled command injection vector exists

high_findings.title: Network Requests to External APIs
high_findings.description: HTTP requests to api.tavily.com and mcp.tavily.com. These are the official endpoints for the Tavily extraction service the skill is designed to use.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Network calls go to legitimate service endpoints - this is the intended purpose of the skill

high_findings.title: Environment Variable Access
high_findings.description: Reads TAVILY_API_KEY from environment for authentication. Standard API key authentication pattern.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Reads own API key from environment - expected behavior for authenticated API client

high_findings.title: Filesystem Access for OAuth Tokens
high_findings.description: Reads OAuth tokens from ~/.mcp-auth/ directory. Standard OAuth token caching behavior.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard OAuth token management - reads cached tokens from standard location

content.value_statement: Get clean markdown or text content from any URL without writing code. Perfect for research and content aggregation.
actual_capabilities: Extract clean markdown or text from specific URLs
Handle up to 20 URLs in a single request
Focus extraction on specific topics using query parameter
Extract from JavaScript-heavy pages with advanced mode
Support both API key and OAuth authentication
limitations: Requires a Tavily API key or account
Rate limits apply based on Tavily subscription
Some complex JS pages may require advanced extraction mode

use_cases.title: Research Assistant
use_cases.description: Extract content from multiple research papers or articles to summarize

use_cases.title: Content Aggregator
use_cases.description: Pull content from multiple sources for analysis or reporting

use_cases.title: Documentation Fetcher
use_cases.description: Extract API docs or technical documentation for offline reading
use_cases.target_user: Developers needing quick access to documentation

prompt_templates.title: Basic URL Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the extract skill to get content from https://example.com/article
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need content from a single URL

prompt_templates.title: Multiple URLs
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract content from these URLs: https://page1.example.com, https://page2.example.com, https://page3.example.com
prompt_templates.scenario: When gathering information from multiple sources

prompt_templates.title: Topic-Focused Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract content about machine learning trends from https://techblog.example.com/ai-research
prompt_templates.scenario: When you want relevant content filtered by topic

prompt_templates.title: JavaScript Page Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract content from https://app.dashboard.example.com using advanced extraction mode
prompt_templates.scenario: When dealing with dynamic or JavaScript-rendered pages

output_examples.output:
# About Example

Welcome to Example.com. We provide innovative solutions...

[Full page content in markdown format]

output_examples.input: Extract information about pricing from https://example.com/pricing
output_examples.output:
Pricing Tier | Monthly | Annual
-- | -- | --
Basic | $9/mo | $90/yr
Pro | $29/mo | $290/yr

best_practices: Use the query parameter to focus extraction on relevant content
Batch multiple URLs (up to 20) in single requests for efficiency
Start with basic extraction, use advanced mode only when needed
Store your API key securely in environment variables
anti_patterns: Using extraction for content you do not have permission to scrape
Extracting too many URLs in parallel and hitting rate limits
Not handling extraction failures gracefully in your workflow
Relying on extraction for real-time or frequently changing content

faq.question: How do I get a Tavily API key?
faq.answer: Sign up at tavily.com and navigate to your account settings to generate an API key.

faq.question: What is the difference between basic and advanced extraction?
faq.answer: Basic extraction works for simple static pages. Advanced extraction handles JavaScript-rendered pages, tables, and complex layouts.

faq.question: How many URLs can I extract at once?
faq.answer: You can extract up to 20 URLs in a single request.

faq.question: Does this skill work with any website?
faq.answer: Most websites work, but some may block automated access or require advanced extraction mode.

faq.question: Can I use OAuth instead of an API key?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill supports OAuth authentication through the MCP server on first run.

faq.question: What formats are supported?
faq.answer: The skill returns content in either markdown or plain text format.
